content.description: Climb the manmade ledge system at the far right end of the crag, two gullies right of the Book.  At the top, a trail leads all the way to the left end of teh crag.  Be careful.
Easy climbing to a ledge and high first bolt leads to sequential moves and technical climbing up a slightly overhanging face.
content.location: Between The Blimp and Fun Wall

content.description:
Starts just left of "The Book" dihedral / crack.

 Quest up the solid but dirty rock.Â
content.location: Starts just left of "The Book" dihedral / crack.

content.description: Start on top of the detached flake on the bottom for a 5.6 climb or start left of the flake for a more difficult slick, dusty climb. Climbing over the detached flake could result in a bad fall onto the flake.
content.location: Look for the detached flake just around the corner right of the book.

content.description: Interesting leftward linkup going past two or three bolts of Fun Wall, through a big flake, connecting a single bolt to Under Fire's anchors and onward over run-out chose to The Blimp's anchors.
content.location: Gradual leftward traverse across Funny Wall area

content.description: This is the polished left-facing dihedral crack.
content.protection:
TR recommended, but leadable. You'll need alot of webbing to rig up this one. Use trees at the top for anchors. See Walk Up for top access info.

 Update, June 2016: 3-4 Bolts have been placed along the route

content.description: Climb only the right hand wall of the book.  Sounds contrived but is actually a good route considering how few routes are available in the area.
content.protection: Good gear is available in the crack at the back of the roof.  Actually a hex drops perfectly in a slot there.

content.description: Blimp is the arete right of The Book. The start of this route is kind of a pain with slippery foot holds and some loose rock. Don't blow it clipping the second bolt. If you do fall while clipping the second bolt it could very well be a ground fall and a twisted ankle due to the not-so-flat-landing, plan accordingly. The second half of the route is still challenging but offers some more solid rock and foot placements with some interesting moves and some exciting exposure.
content.protection: The route has four bolts plus a two bolt anchor. If you're worried about falling at the second bolt  then bring a stick clip or crash pad.

content.description: This area features a prominent dihedral and a bolted arete.
